description.narrative: 1.3. National and provincial government authorities and civil society have monitoring, analysis and planning tools to improve child- sensitive budgeting., which contributes to Adolescent Empowerment, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children, Child Poverty / Public Finance For Children (Covid), Children In Urban Settings / Local Governance, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Policy Advocacy â€“ Urban, Civil Society, Parliament, Environment, Public Finance And Local Governance, Social Exclusion â€“ Data And Evidence, Social Protection. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2020, children and adolescents, especially the most disadvantaged, benefit from a social protection framework, and monitoring and evaluation systems to improve public policies and social investment and reduce inequity gaps.

sector.narrative: Adolescents participating in or leading civic engagement initiatives (including in humanitarian settings)
Child poverty analysis towards policy change (Profiling, mapping and identifying drivers of multi-dimensional and monetary poverty of children, modelling and simulation of policy options)
PF4C: Improving public expenditure effectiveness / efficiency

related-activity.ref: 0240/A0/05/881 PR 1: SOCIAL INCLUSION & CHILD RIGHT MON

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: 1.3. National and provincial government authorities and civil society have monitoring, analysis and planning tools to improve child- sensitive budgeting.

description.narrative: Thanks to UNICEF's continued advocacy and technical and financial cooperation, important results were achieved with the National MoF to advance the institutionalization of C-PEM and PF4C work, favoring evidence generation that is key to guide policy decisions and protect and improve budget allocation for children, particularly in times of economic hardship and fiscal constraints. Updated analyses of investment in children at national and CPS levels were published by MoF; National Budget Office formally introduced childhood budgeting as cross-sectoral dimension in its work agenda. Costing exercises contributed to design of public initiatives with high impact on childhood and adolescence. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:20/12/2019

title.narrative: Number of studies conducted and published that orient the financing of policies directed to children.

Amount (in national currency) allocated from the national budget to new (or expanded) COVID-19 social protection programmes that directly or indirectly benefit children (including on-budget development partner funds) in the reporting year [COVID]

actual.value: 2020:ARG$687.751 million. The amount represents the 2.17% of GDP

title.narrative: (NOT VALID after Dec 31 2017) Information and reports on child-focused public expenditures (direct, indirect and total) is made available by governments

baseline.value: GPdN 24 provinces updated 2001-2009 and 7 selected provinces updated 2001-2014

title.narrative: 3.4 Nationally owned measurement of the share of public spending in health, education and/or social protection benefiting children in households living in the poorest region and/or the poorest quintile is in place for use in policy development

actual.value: 2019:Updated information of investment in children in health, education and social protection of National and Consolidated Public Sector Levels was produced. Distributive Incidence analysis of investment in children is expected for Dec 2019.
